column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Know Proper Table Manners in China
#Text=Table manners are important in every culture ; however , there is no universal rule for table manners .
#Text=Like many cultures , the Chinese have specific rules of etiquette when sharing a meal .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Know where to sit .
#Text=The seat of honor faces the door .
#Text=To show respect , choose a different seat .
#Text=The person with the lowest status sits with their back to the door , directly opposite the guest of honor .
#Text=When in doubt , wait for the host to seat you .
#Text=Do not begin the meal until everyone arrives .
#Text=After that , wait for the highest ranking or oldest person to begin eating before you start .
#Text=Keep both hands visible .
#Text=In China , it is alright to put your elbows on the table .
#Text=Do not gesture with your chopsticks .
#Text=Never point them at someone else .
#Text=This is highly disrespectful .
#Text=Chopsticks are used in the right hand , even for left-handed people .
#Text=Avoid banging dishes with your chopsticks .
#Text=This is considered to be the behavior of a beggar .
#Text=Pour tea for other people , but not yourself .
#Text=Do not fill the cup all the way , as this means you want them to leave .
#Text=Do not point the teapot 's spout at anyone .
#Text=Never stick your chopsticks straight up in your rice when eating .
#Text=This signifies incense for the dead .
#Text=Be aware that meals are usually family style .
#Text=Expect people to use their chopsticks to serve their food .
#Text=Often , the host will use their own chopsticks to serve you food .
#Text=Do your best to try everything .
#Text=Do n't hog a dish just because you like it ; this is not polite behavior .
#Text=There are people that need to eat other than you , so it 's important to share .
#Text=Also , do n't refuse a dish because you do n't like it .
#Text=Eat at least a little in order to be polite .
#Text=Be aware that many Chinese dishes contain animal bones .
#Text=These bones can be spat out and placed to the right of your plate or , if available , a trash can on the floor .
#Text=Know that , if drinking alcohol , you may be expected to 干杯 , which is translated to mean " Cheers " , but actually means " drink the entire glass of alcohol " .
#Text=If you are a special guest , every single person will toast to you .
#Text=When clinking glasses , try to place the rim of your glass below theirs .
#Text=This indicates that you respect them .
#Text=Know that , in general , the host pays for the entire meal .
#Text=If you are the host , you are expected to offer to pay , though nine times out of ten , they will refuse .
#Text=If you invited them to the meal , you will pay for everyone .
#Text=Tips
#Text=For banquets and large dinners , pace yourself .
#Text=They will be serving a large amount of food .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Never try to secretly pay the bill for your host .
#Text=This is extremely rude .
#Text=However , if you are the host , you may have to pay the bill without letting anyone else know .
#Text=The battle for the check can be intense .
